"Every Sinner Has A Future": Supreme Court Commutes Death Sentence Imposed On Man For Rape & Murder Of 4 Year Old Girl

The Supreme Court has commuted the death sentence awarded to a man accused of rape and murder of a four-year-old girl.

The bench comprising Justices UU Lalit, S. Ravindra Bhat and Bela M. Trivedi observed that the maximum punishment prescribed may not always be the determinative factor for repairing the crippled psyche of the offender.

The Trial Court had awarded death sentence to the accused Firoz for the following offenses:
- Section 302 of IPC (murder): Death sentence
- Section 363 of IPC: 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2000
- Section 366 of IPC: 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2000
- Sections 376(2)(i), 376(2)(m) of IPC and POCSO Act: Life imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2000

The High Court dismissed his appeal and confirmed the death sentence.

Upon re-appreciating the evidence, the Supreme Court found that the prosecution had proved the circumstances conclusively beyond reasonable doubt.

Regarding the death sentence, the bench noted: "Every saint has a past and every sinner has a future." They emphasized the principles of restorative justice and the opportunity for an offender to become a socially useful individual.

The Court commuted the death sentence to:
- Life imprisonment for the murder charge
- 20 years imprisonment for the rape charge instead of imprisonment for the remainder of his natural life

The conviction for other offenses was affirmed, with all punishments to run concurrently.

Key observations included the importance of balancing retributive and restorative justice, and providing opportunities for rehabilitation.
title: The Supreme Court has commuted the death sentence of a man, who had sexually assaulted and killed a four-year-old girl in Madhya Pradesh in April 2013, to 20-year imprisonment.

The Supreme Court upheld the conviction but modified the sentence, converting death penalty to life imprisonment for murder and 20 years for rape.
